page.title: 02The Old Airfield 1
page.content: During the Second World War in 1942, a large area of flat, agricultural land was taken away from Rockingham Estates by the Ministry of Defence to be used as an airfield. Three concrete runways, which formed a triangle were built and a perimeter track. Five enormous hangers of corrugated iron were built to house the aircraft. A camp for the airmen, quarters for the officers, a control tower, gun sites, ammunition and fuel dumps were constructed. The airfield was used as a training unit for many squadrons of the Royal Air Force between 1943 and 1945. They were trained to fly Wellington Bombers. Parts of these were repaired by Booklands Aviation Ltd, who used the United Counties Garage in Desborough. Many airmen who were trained here married local girls and settled in the surrounding area after the war.
